_comment: STORY TEMPLATE - Use this as a reference for creating new stories
_instructions: Copy this file and fill in your story details
Remove all fields starting with _ before loading
Required fields: title, description, initial_message, characters (at least one User type)
All other fields are optional but recommended for rich storytelling
Character types: User (player), Main (primary NPCs), Support (secondary), Antagonist, Cameo, NPC
playthrough_id will be NULL for templates (automatically handled by loader)
title: Your Story Title
description: A brief description of your story (1-3 sentences). This appears in the story selection screen.
initial_message: The opening narration that sets the scene and draws the player into your story. This should be evocative, set the tone, and end at a decision point or interesting moment. Can be several paragraphs long.

characters._comment: USER CHARACTER - Required! The player character
characters.name: You
characters.appearance: Brief physical description (can be vague to allow player imagination)
characters.backstory: Player character's background, motivations, current situation. Sets the context for why they're in this story.
characters.speech_patterns: How this character speaks (formal, casual, etc.)
characters.sentence_structure: Description of how they construct sentences
characters.decision_style: How they make decisions (analytical, impulsive, emotional, etc.)
characters.internal_contradiction: A way they contradict themselves (makes them human)

characters.name: Character Name
characters.backstory: Detailed background and how they relate to the story
characters.internal_contradiction: Preaches honesty but hides their past

characters._comment: SUPPORT CHARACTER EXAMPLE - Secondary recurring characters
characters.name: Support Character
characters.backstory: Background relevant to their role in the story
characters._note: Support characters can have fewer enhanced fields if they're less central

characters.name: Antagonist Name
characters.appearance: Physical description emphasizing threatening or opposing qualities
characters.backstory: What made them an antagonist, their motivations
characters.speech_patterns: How they speak (often measured, threatening, or manipulative)
characters._note: Good antagonists have clear motivations, not just evil for evil's sake

locations._comment: Locations where scenes can take place
locations.name: Location Name - Specific Area
locations.description: Vivid description that sets the atmosphere and details. Help the AI paint the scene.
locations.scope: room, building, neighborhood, district, city, region

locations.name: Another Location
locations.description: Each location should have sensory details and emotional atmosphere
locations._parent_example: For hierarchical locations, you could add parent_location_id after it's in the database

relationships._comment: Define how characters know each other - critical for realistic interactions
relationships.history: Summary of their history together, key events that shaped the relationship
Were best friends as kids, lost touch for 10 years, recently reconnected. Still comfortable with each other but much has changed.

story_arcs._comment: Story arcs structure the narrative progression
story_arcs.name: Arc Name
story_arcs.description: What this arc is about, what character development or plot progression happens
story_arcs._is_active_note: 1 = active at story start, 0 = inactive until conditions met
story_arcs._start_condition_note: Empty {} means active from start. Otherwise: {"flags": ["flag_name"]}
story_arcs._completion_note: What story flags indicate this arc is complete

episodes._comment: Optional: Break arcs into smaller episodes
episodes.name: Episode Name
episodes._trigger_note: Flags needed to start this episode

_additional_notes.character_depth: The enhanced character fields (core_values, fears, contradictions, etc.) help the AI create more consistent and realistic characters
_additional_notes.relationships: Define ALL important relationships, even antagonistic ones. This helps the AI understand character dynamics
_additional_notes.story_flags: Story flags are set during play to track progress. Name them clearly (e.g., 'met_main_character', 'discovered_secret', 'completed_quest')
_additional_notes.locations: More locations give the AI more places to move the story. Include atmosphere and sensory details
_additional_notes.balancing_scope: You don't need to define everything. The AI can create minor NPCs and locations on the fly. Focus on what's important to your story
_additional_notes.testing: Start with a simple version and add detail as you test. You can always enhance later
